text.p: The following are the main stories from Friday's Albanian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Two of Albania's biggest concerns, Vefa Holding and Kamberi, have agreed to slash monthly interest for money deposited with them from eight-ten percent to five percent by the beginning of next year.
- Gjallica company has begun giving back promised sums to depositors from its high interest money scheme after it halted payments for two days.

- A meeting of the key opposition Socialist Party's 104-member general steering committee voted with a crushing majority against a motion calling for an extraordinary congress in February and a confidence vote for the leadership.
- Turkey's Foreign Ministry denied the self-styled republic of Kosovo, Serbia's southern region mainly inhabited by Albanians, has opened an embassy in Ankara.
- The National Front and the Legitimacy (Monarchy) Party plan to found the United Albanian Right after the candidate of their United Right of Shkoder won the mayorship of Shkoder.
- Albanian President Sali Berisha awarded the "Honour of the Nation" medal to the first Roman Catholic Cardinal of Albania, Mikel Koliqi.
- Fatos Nano, the jailed leader of the opposition Socialist Party, has appealed to senior party leaders to leave aside differences and make peace.
- About 1,500 pigs have died in a mystery epidemic.

- President Sali Berisha has written off the debts parties incurred during the two recent electoral campaigns since they did not manage to win the necessary amount of votes to profit from the state budget funds.
